assistant: Nursing is a developing, professional field of care dedicated to helping individuals, families, and communities maintain or regain health, prevent illness, and cope with health problems. It is adaptable to changing situations and settings, and it emphasizes culturally sensitive, individualized care (transcultural nursing) to meet the health beliefs, values, and practices of diverse people. Cultural competence and integration of knowledge into practice, education, and research are core components of modern nursing.

Transcultural nursing is a branch of nursing focused on delivering culturally sensitive and effective care to individuals, families, and groups from diverse cultural backgrounds. Key points:

- It aims to meet the cultural needs of patients by understanding and respecting their health beliefs, values, and practices, and integrating them into care.
- Originated with Madeleine Leininger (1979) and uses comparative study of cultures to inform universal nursing concepts and culturally appropriate practice.
- Includes the integration of transcultural concepts, theories, and practices into education, research, and clinical applications.
- Seeks to improve knowledge and practice by providing culturally congruent care across all levels of health care institutions, with nurses in a privileged position to implement it.
